subject: Re: Developments
msgSnippet: I never ever thought I d be reading in Quikscript! A fascinating experience. Also, reading it slowly contributes to thoughtfulness. And as I am reading it, my
messageBody:
I never ever thought I'd be reading in Quikscript! A fascinating
experience.
Also, reading it slowly contributes to thoughtfulness.
And as I am reading it, my fluency in reading Quikscript is also rising!

Thank you for putting up the file.

I'll let you know after I've finished (and developed the requisite
fluency in typing QS as well) whether I can fit in the time to help with
editing the balance.


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "cossyrosario" <cossyrosario@...>
wrote:
>
> Thank you. You're most helpful indeed!
>
> I will look at the Genesis file first. I may find it heavy going
(after
> all, I'm still learning Quikscript, still somewhere near the midpoint
of
> the manual). On the other hand, I know the book exceedingly well,
having
> studied it and also read it devotionally (along with the other 66
books
> of course) for years. So maybe I might find the Quikscript Genesis
> easier to read than (say) QS Alice in Wonderland, simply because I
> should be able to anticipate what an unfamiliar outline would mean.
>
> Let's see what happens.
>
> After reading the file (or attempting to), I'll have to see how I can
> organize my time.
> Then I'll let you know.
>
> And I hope (if I volunteer to help) that I won't let you down by not
> being a good enough QS Editor!
>
>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "tim_rice09" tim_rice09@
> wrote:
> >
> > Let's see if I can answer these, keep a running tally please.
> >
> > USFM is a markup scheme that makes working with Biblical text
easier.
> It takes care of everything from verse numbers to footnotes. Bibledit
is
> a great FOSS program that organizes books in USFM and can export
> formatted Bible archives for everything from the Sword Project
programs
> to Open Document, which LibreOffice can turn into very nice PDF files.
> >
> > You're right, QS does not have an official placement in Unicode,
yet.
> Right now what's referred to as "Unicode Quickscript" is a group of
> placeholder codes in the Private Use Area. It's an ugly, ugly hack,
but
> a lot less ugly than the substitution schemes that have to be used
> otherwise.
> >
> > Right now I'm running a server where the grunt work is being done.
If
> you or anyone else in this group is interested, I can pass on the
> information they need to access it.
> >
> > Also, there is a copy of Genesis in the files section of this group.
A
> word of warning, though, it's yet to receive the care of a good
editor.
> >
> > That was all of them, right?
> >
> > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "cossyrosario" cossyrosario@
> wrote:
> > >
> > > What is Bibledit? and what is a USFMed file?
> > > I thought that Unicode doesn't have a scheme for Quikscript. Is
> Kingsley Unicode a special branch of Unicode?
> > >
> > > Questions, questions, questions.
> > >
> > > If only I were not so far behind in matters computer.
> > >
> > > If only I could read the Bible in Quikscript (at least parts of
it).
> > >
> > > If only I could help you put part of the 20% into Quikscript. It
> would be the best way of learning Quikscript.
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "tim_rice09" <tim_rice09@>
> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Do guys remember a while back when some of us were discussing
> transcribing the classics into Quickscript? Well, after a bit of
> creative hackery (find/replace all ad nauseum) I have the World
English
> Bible nearly 80% in Quickscript. Running low on common words, the true
> fun is soon to start. If anyone has the interest and time, it would be
> amazing if they could adopt a book or two and sculpt the remaining
bits
> of non-markup Latin away. I chose a USFMed file compatible with the
very
> capable program Bibledit to make versification and layout a non-issue.
> The Quickscript text follows the Kingsley Unicode scheme so an input
> method that supports it is key. Aside from that, come one come all to
> the virtual transcribing hall.
> > > >
> > >
> >
>
